newsitem.title: INDIA: SQUASH-EYLES AND NICOL STAY ON PATH FOR FINAL.
newsitem.headline: SQUASH-EYLES AND NICOL STAY ON PATH FOR FINAL.

text.p: Australian Rodney Eyles, favourite to win the tournament, and title-holder Peter Nicol of Scotland remained on course on Thursday for a clash in the final of the $105,000 Mahindra International, the second richest tournament outside the World Open.
Nicol ended the hopes of former world junior champion Ahmed Barada of Egypt, who had beaten sixth seed Englishman Mark Chaloner to reach the quarter-finals, but not without a struggle.
Nicol eventually beat Barada 13-15 17-15 15-8 15-9, surviving a crisis when he was a game and 14-15 down.
At that stage Barada's coach was warned for illegal coaching and the teenager went all-out to snatch a two game lead.
"I think that was the best thing that could have happened," said Nicol. "The effort tired him and after he lost the second game I felt I could win."

Eyles had a more comfortable passage through to the semifinals, beating Paul Gregory of Greece 15-8 15-8 15-7 with an outstanding attacking display, scoring heavily at the front with drops and frustrating his opponent into an outburst of ill-temper on the penultimate point.
"In another couple of years you might be an OK referee," Gregory shouted at New Zealand referee Gavin Whyte. He was immediately deducted a code of conduct penalty point.

Nicol's semifinal opponent will be England's Simon Parke who beat Zubair Jahan 15-11 15-17 7-15 15-7 15-4 while Eyles faces another Englishman, Mark Cairns, 13-15 15-6 15-12 15-4 winner over Ireland's Derek Ryan.
